title: Socialization in dogs
detail:
• Maternal care and handling crucial in first 3 weeks
• Litter maters are crucial during the transition period
• Socialization period is 4-12 weeks
• Lack can lead to fear and aggression, and inability to communicate

title: Dental care
detail:
• Kibble reduces buildup while wet food debris can adhere to the teeth
• Food and water additives available
• Water additives work by reducing bacterial count in the mouth
• Chew toys also reduce buildup; dense rubber toys and rawhide strips work best
• Dried hooves and nylon chew bones and ropes can cause injury to gingival tissue and damage to teeth; tennis balls can lead to exposure of dental pulp

title: 9 Cs of effective communication
detail:
• Clarity
• Conciseness
• Credibility
• Creativity (to create a lasting impression)
• Correctness (pronunciation and grammar)
• Coherence
• Completeness
• Courtesy
• Concreteness

title: Veterinary ethics
detail:
• Descriptive ethics: Study of ethical views of vets and veterinary professionals regarding their behavior and attitudes
• Official veterinary ethics: Creation of ethical standards adopted by organizations of professionals and imposed on their members
• Normative ethics: Search for correct principles of good and bad, right and wrong, justice or injustice
• Administrative ethics: Actions by administrative government bodies that regulate veterinary practice and activities in which vets engage

title: Expired drugs
detail: • Must be dissolved in an appropriate pouch that inactivates the medication, rendering them irretrievable, then disposed of in the trash

title: Destruction of controlled substances
detail:
• Destroyed inventory and method of destruction must be logged, and two witnesses should sign off on the destruction (DEA form 41)
• Previously, controlled substances had to be submitted to a reverse distributor for destruction

title: Drug loss and theft
detail:
• Any loss equal to or higher than 3% of a controlled substance must be reported to the DEA
• In case of theft, both DEA and local police need to be notified
• Some states may require that pharmacy and veterinary boards be notified as well

title: Anticoagulant agents used in blood collections tubes
detail:
• Potassium citrate
• Lithium heparin
• Sodium heparin
• Ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid (EDTA)

title: Serum separator tubes
detail:
• Vacuum-sealed tubes containing silica particles to accelerate blood clotting and a polymer gel to separate serum from cells during centrifugation
• Necessary for clinical chemistry, immunology, and serology tests
• Not necessary for monitoring of therapeutic levels of  phenobarbital, theophylline, and digoxin (red top tube used instead)

title: Privacy Act of 1974
detail:
• "No agency shall disclose any record … to any person, or to another agency, except pursuant to a written request by, or with the prior written consent of, the individual to whom the record pertains"
• Many practices request clients to fill out medical release forms if clients ask for their records to be released to others

title: Fair Debt Collection Practices Act of 1996
detail:
• Protects the public from unethical collection procedures
• Only allows phone calls bw 8 am to 9 pm
• Collecting agencies are not allowed to impersonate lawyers or government agencies
• Client’s name, address and telephone number, occupation, driver's license number, employment address, total balance due account, copy of client information sheet, and signature of client guaranteeing payment for services rendered can be shared w collection agencies

title: Other laws veterinary practices are subject to
detail:
• Uniformed Services Employment and Reemployment Rights Act
• Immigration Reform and Control Act
• Employee Polygraph Protection Act
• Family and Medical Leave Act (practices with 50+ employees)

title: Urine dipstick vs. urine sediment
detail:
• Urine dipstick checks for urine glucose, pH, leukocytes, blood, ketones, bilirubin, and nitrates
• Urine sediment checks for WBC, RBC, epithelial cells, bacteria, casts, and crystals

title: Hearing protection
detail:
• Should be available when noise levels reach 85 dB
• OSHA requires noise measurement, noise protection, and hearing testing when noise exceeds 85 dB

title: Compassion fatigue
detail:
• Natural result of being a caregiver; occurs only in caregiving roles
• Has a short and sudden onset of symptoms
• Can be resolved by time spent away from caregiving role
• Different from burn-out, which can occur in any job and over a longer period of time in the form of a decrease in job satisfaction)
• Results in cognitive, behavioral, emotional, spiritual, interpersonal, and physical symptoms
• Social symptoms include isolation, intolerance, mistrust
• Pain is a physical symptom
• Depression is an emotional symptom
• Nightmares are a behavioral symptom
• Decreased concentration is a cognitive sign
• Questioning life's meaning is a spiritual sign
• Lack of non–work-related aspects of life is an interpersonal sign
• Dread of working w certain co-workers is a work-related sign

title: PPE in radiographs
detail:
• Min. PPE is lead gown, thyroid collar, and lead gloves
• Some practices recommend goggles too, but OSHA does not require it

title: Euthanasia
detail:
• Comes from the Greek terms eu/good and thanatos/death.
• An animal should be presented to an owner after euthanasia in a waterproof body bag
• When a client is not present to sign a euthanasia form, they must inform two team members of their wish to euthanize and both must document the conversation in the medical record
• If children are involved, don’t use euphemisms like PTS (may scare them from sleeping or lead to misunderstanding that pet may wake up); they can be present during PTS

title: Nonsterile procedure
detail: • Any procedure that does not require aseptic techniques (abscess debridement, dental procedures, anal sac expression, ear flush, etc.)

title: Red Flag Rule
detail:
• Businesses must check identity of a person who presents a credit card for payment
• Established to decrease fraud and identity theft

title: Fairness to Pets Act
detail: • Gives clients the option to purchase medication wherever they choose

title: Examination of surgical patients
detail:
• Surgical patients must be examined w/in 12 hours of anesthesia
• Exam must be documented in the medical record

title: SWOT
detail:
• SWOT analysis is used to improve the practice from a marketing standpoint
• Acronym for strengths, weaknesses, opportunities, threats

title: Types of marketing
detail:
• Building sign, lectures, media advertising, etc. are external marketing
• Web page or social media are internal marketing
• Yellow pages and newspaper ads are direct marketing
• Client education is indirect marketing
• 70% of phone shoppers should become clients

title: Inactive medical record
detail: • A client who has not been seen for a year or more

title: Missed charges
detail:
• Account for approximately 10% of gross revenue
• Managing inventory and investigating discrepancies help decrease them

title: Incorporeal property
detail:
• No physical substance, but still transferable (e.g. practice goodwill)
• Aka intangible property

title: Medical records
detail:
• Must be written in blue or black ink
• Author of the entry must date and initial each time an entry is made
• Correction fluid cannot be used—corrections must be made by drawing a single line thru, rewritten, and initialed
• Only standard and approved abbreviations are used
• Must be legible

title: Computerized records
detail:
• Aka paperless records
• Filed under the client's last name and client number
• A disadvantage is lack of medical details

title: Staggering appointments
detail:
• Help reduce client overload at the front desk
• Appointments should be staggered every 5 minutes
• Can be set for every 15–30 minutes or more, or multiple can happen at the same time, but staggering will reduce overload either way

title: Appointment length
detail:
• May vary for reasons such as specific clients, type of appointment, and the veterinarian
• Usually does not vary due to type of patient

title: Dispensing limits of controlled substances
detail:
• Class I is labeled for research only
• Class II is written Rx only w no refills
• New Rx must be written for the next 30 days if needed
• Class III and IV are written Rx w five refills
• Class V has no dispensing limits (low abuse potential)
• Refills are available for 6 months (every 30 days); after 6 months a new Rx must be submitted to the pharmacy

title: Components human voice
detail:
• Four components:
• Volume
• Tone
• Rate
• Quality

title: Employee discounts
detail: • Discounts greater than 20% are reported as fringe benefits and reported to the IRS as pay

title: Pregnancy of techs
detail: • Discrimination against pregnant staff is illegal, so they should be counseled on safety issues but remain free to decide what safety level they obtain

title: Indemnity insurance
detail:
• Provides compensation for injured or sick pets
• Paid directly to the client after services are rendered—client still pays for services in full and submits receipts to retrieve compensation

title: Rider
detail: • An extension of coverage that can be purchased and added to a base medical policy

title: Entering meds into record
detail: • 0.4 mL Cefazolin (100 mg/mL) IV

title: Eye wash station
detail: • Must be w/in 10 seconds from any team member potentially exposed to a chemical

title: Spill kit
detail: • Should include cat litter, dustpan and broom, nitrile gloves, eye protection, and a laminated copy of the cleanup procedure

title: Staff meetings
detail: • To avoid loss of interest and maximize value of time spent, meetings should not last longer than 45 min

title: Dispensing fee
detail:
• Added to a product after markup is determined
• Covers costs of filling an Rx such as label on the bottle, vial used, wear and tear on the label writer machine, tech’s time used to fill it

title: Formalin : tissue
detail:
• 10:01
• When submitting a tissue sample for pathology, sample should contain 10% formalin at 10 times the volume of the tissue

title: HCS Pictograms
detail:
• Hazard Communication Standard pictograms
• Skull and crossbones: Acute toxicity (fatal or toxic)
• Bomb: Explosives
• Exclamation mark: Skin irritant
• Flame: Flammables

title: Anaerobic culture
detail:
• Culture that requires the absence of air
• Should be kept at room temperature and processed w/in 48 hours of collection

title: Message components in communication
detail:
• A message has three components:
• Nonverbal skills (body language) contribute 55% of the message
• Paraverbal skills (the way words are spoken) contribute 38% to the message
• Verbal skills contribute 7%

title: Drug logs
detail:
• Law requires controlled substance logs
• Have "C" on the bottle
• Should include client name and address, patient name, reason for use, amount administered, balance of drug after use, and initials
• Class II controlled substances must have their own separate log and invoices kept separately
• Controlled substance logs must be kept for 2 years after the last recorded entry

title: Inventory log
detail:
• Product name
• Strength and count in a full bottle
• Date of purchase
• Name and address of vendor
• Date and time of inventory
• Log quantity
• Physical quantity
• Any discrepancy found
• Initials

title: Treatment plans
detail:
• Techs should present tx plans since they are familiar w the pet
• Vets should diagnose, prescribe meds, and perform procedures; they should not discuss financial issues

title: SOAP
detail:
• Subjective: Reason for the visit, history, and observations made by the client
• Objective: Information gathered from the patient, physical examination, or diagnostic workup
• Assessment: Conclusion and definitive diagnosis
• Plan: Treatment, surgery, medication, and diagnostics recommended

title: Calls placed on hold
detail:
• Clients should be placed on hold for a max. of 1 min
• Must check in w client at 1 min
• Offer to call back if client is to be on hold for more than 2 min

title: Employee benefits
detail: • Health insurance, dental/vision insurance, continuing education, vacation, sick leave, holiday pay, professional liability insurance, disability insurance, life insurance, retirement plans, dues and licenses, veterinary care

title: PASS
detail:
• Acronym to remember when using a fire extinguisher
• Pull, Aim, Squeeze, Sweep

title: SDS
detail:
• Safety data sheets
• Fact lists for chemicals
• Information that must be included:
• Identity of the chemical
• Physical and chemical characteristics
• Health hazards
• Permissible exposure limits
• Whether the product is a carcinogen
• Emergency first aid procedures
• Specific hazards

title: Business lifecycle
detail:
• Four stages:
• Introduction
• Growth
• Maturity
• Decline

title: Malpractice
detail: • Incorrect drug administration, incorrect strength of drug administration, failure to clean animals that have defecated and/or urinated, abandonment, leaving foreign objects in a patient after surgery, failure to exercise good judgment, failure to communicate, loss or damage to patients' personal property, disease transmission, a patient attacking another, use of defective equipment or medication are considered acts of malpractice

title: Mission, vision, and values
detail:
• Mission: Purpose of the hospital; fundamental reason that the practice exists
• Vision: Desired future of the practice
• Core values: Guiding principles that are not to be compromised during change

title: Accounts receivable
detail:
• Money owed to a business for services rendered or sold and not paid for at the time of service
• Should not exceed 1.5% of gross revenue; anything more can decrease the cash flow of the practice

title: Dosimetry records
detail:
• Kept for 30 years
• Team members should always have access

title: Ergonomics
detail: • Science that studies the relationship bw people and their work environments

title: Motion economy
detail:
• Organization of material in a logical sequence
• Positioning of objects as close to the point of use as possible
• Amount of time and degree of motion required to perform a given task

title: Petty cash
detail: • Cash that is set aside in the practice to purchase items needed for business when a check is not available

title: Vaccines in horses
detail:
• Core vaccines
• Tetanus
• Rabies
• Eastern/western equine encephalomyelitis
• West Nile Virus
• Risk-based vaccines
• Anthrax
• Botulism
• Equine Herpes Virus
• Equine Viral Arteritis
• Equine influenza
• Potomac Horse Fever
• Strangles (Streptococcus equi)

title: Informed consent
detail:
• Requires full disclosure of facts that are necessary to make an intelligent decision
• Includes risks, benefits, current research, cost estimate, treatments, etc.

title: Feeding pregnant dogs
detail:
• High-quality, easily digestible puppy food should be fed to pregnant dogs starting at 5 weeks (third trimester)
• Provides necessary calcium, phosphorus, and calories needed for fetal growth, milk development, nursing, and energy
• Should continue until puppies are weaned
• Gestation period in dogs is 9 weeks (63-65 days)

title: Librela (bedinvetmab)
detail:
• Monoclonal antibody directed against nerve growth factor, which is a key player in the pain pathway
• Effective for osteoarthritis pain
• Very safe—effects comparable to NSAIDs but safer for dogs w kidney disease
• Minimally metabolized in kidney and liver
• Injection
• Side effects on research only; include elevated BUN levels, bacterial skin infections, UTIs, inflammation at injection site

title: Reversal agents
detail:
• Naloxone for opioids including apomorphine
• But it reverses the respiratory and CNS effects, not cardiac changes or vomiting; if used to induce vomiting (e.g. in dogs ingesting chocolate), Cerenia or ondansetron should be given to stop vomiting
• Yohimbine for alpha-2 agonists
• Flumazenil for benzodiazepines
• Atropine is not a true reversal but is used as antidote for blue-green algae, organophosphate, carbamate, and muscarinic mushroom toxicities

title: Psittacine (parrot) diet
detail:
• 40-50% from cereals and whole grains, usually from pellets fortified w vitamins and minerals; provides protein, fiber, vit B, fat
• 20-30% from vegetables like broccoli, winter squash, dark leafy greens, sweet potatoes; provides fiber, vit A and K, carbs, and some calcium
• Avocado is toxic
• 15-20% from fruits like pomegranate, berries, papaya
• 5% from meats, insects, fish; provides fat, protein, calcium, omega fatty acids
• Cooked eggs, legumes, lean meats can be given in small quantities
• 0% seeds—no nutritional value

title: Chelonian diet
detail:
• Land tortoises are mostly herbivores, but may scavenge for small rodents and insects
• Only require 5% protein in captivity
• 10% from fruits like pears, peaches, grapes, plums, dates, strawberries, raspberries, mangoes, melons, papayas, tomatoes
• 85% from vegetables like collards, dandelions, cabbage, broccoli, squash, kale
• Aquatic turtles require a much larger portion of protein, but should still receive vegetables

title: Toxoplasma gondii
detail:
• Cats are the intermediate and definitive hosts
• All warm-blooded animals can be intermediate hoses
• Cats are usually asymptomatic, but severe in kittens w depression, lethargy, fever, ascites, and death
• Humans:
• Usually asymptomatic or show flu symptoms
• Immunocompromised people can develop myocarditis, lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly, encephalitis, hepatomegaly
• Congenital abnormalities possible if a woman is negative at conception but become positive during pregnancy; risks include damage to eyes and brain, and abortion (subsequent pregnancies not of concern)

title: De-escalating difficult clients
detail:
• Invite to an exam room for privacy but w another staff
• Sit down beside client if safe (no desk in bw)
• Thank client for permitting you to help determine the problem
• Let them talk
• Use active and reflective listening
• Be empathetic
• Agree w client whenever feasible
• Don’t justify the clinical action that is the cause for concern
• If a mistake was made, discuss it and offer options to rectify the situation
• Place hospital policies in a positive light
• Try to provide an acceptable solution
• Permit client to save face or de-escalate w/out much intervention
• Don’t argue
• Contact police if unsafe

title: IMHA drugs
detail:
• Mainstay of IMHA therapy are immunosuppressive doses of steroids (glucocorticoids) like prednisone, prednisolone, dexamethasone
• Response is usually not sufficient, so most will also go on immunosuppressants like cyclosporine, azathioprine, cyclophosphamide
• High risk of thromboembolism in dogs w IMHA, so clopidogrel (a platelet aggregation inhibitor) can be used as preventive

title: Scope of previous history
detail:
• Place and date of birth, or when client obtained patient
• Preventive programs to date incl. vaccines, preventives, S/N status, activity level
• Where patient is mostly spending time
• Previous medical conditions and conditions or which patient is currently receiving care
• Current meds, effectiveness and responses
• Nutritional history incl. weight, any loss/gain, diet
• Known reactions to meds, env. Factors
• Any previous blood transfusions
• Normal behavior

title: Scope of recent history
detail:
• Presenting or chief complaint
• When patient was last normal
• Characterization of problem—duration, onset, severity, frequency, behavioral changes, worsening/improving
• Current meds
• Treatment attempts and responses
• Concerns and questions for the vet
• Diet that day, incl. treats
• Any changes to diet, env., number of people or pets in the home, schedule

title: History for herd animals
detail:
• Housing type and conditions, co-mingling w other species
• Type and source of water, incl. recent changes
• Type and source of feed, incl. recent changes, appetite changes, supplier changes
• Overall herd health status, outstanding tests
• Contact w wildlife
• Details about use of animals (dairy, lactation, meat, etc.)

title: Flushing esophageal feeding tube
detail:
• Before and after feeding
• 10-15 mL

title: Dogs’ use of food for energy
detail: • Dogs use 50-80% of their diet on a dry matter basis for energy

title: ABC behavior model
detail:
• Antecedent (stimulus preceding unwanted behavior)
• B (behavior)
• C (consequence)

title: Stages of grief
detail:
• Denial
• Bargaining
• Anger
• Guilt
• Depression
• Resolution

title: Types of grief
detail:
• Disenfranchised grief: Lack of understanding from others
• Complicated grief: Leads to prolonged, intense response
• Anticipatory grief: Due to impending loss
• Distorted grief: Extreme, dramatic, deep reaction to loss

title: Post-op recommendations for perianal surgery
detail:
• Straining must be minimized to avoid pressure on sutures and delayed healing
• High-fiber diet used to soften stool
• Tootsie roll consistency ideal
• Laxatives like polyethylene glycol or lactulose used as well
• If patient develops diarrhea, diet/laxative should be stopped or adjusted
• Rump must be kept clean and dry; can be rinsed off and dried after defecating
• Straining, vocalizing suggest pain that must be controlled

title: Taurine
detail:
• Amino acid that is key in the function of ocular, platelet, neurological, myocardial, immune, and reproductive systems
• Found in meat, seafood, fish in high levels
• Cats produce less compared to other specific
• Used to be lacking in commercial cat diets; led to ocular damage, DCM (usually a dog disease)
• Grain/cereal-based diets, vegetarian diets, and dog food have no taurine, so cats fed these diets need to be supplemented

title: Reasons for barking in dogs
detail:
• Defending territory
• Soliciting play
• Boredom; acting out for attention
• Requesting food
• Response to anxiety, fear, stress
• Separation anxiety—different from the above bc not a “normal” reason to bark, needs to be addressed

title: Habituation vs. desensitization
detail:
• Habituation: Response to the same stimulus decreases in intensity over time
• Stimulus is presented w/out controlling its intensity
• Involves no rewards
• Risks sensitization (i.e. developing stronger response)
• Desensitization: Involves identifying a stress-free place to being, gradually introducing fear-inducing stimulus, and increasing duration and intensity over time
• Rewarding, backing up if needed necessary

title: Blister beetle
detail:
• Toxic in horses (cantharidin is the toxic principle)
• Most commonly ass w ingestion of beetle-contaminated alfa alfa
• Common in the Midwest and Great Plains
• Causes irritation to mucous membranes, ulcerations in the mouth, GI tract, urinary system
• Signs include colic, increased or frequent urination, hemoglobinuria, hematuria, and less commonly cardiac and neurological signs
• Can be fatal; guarded prognosis even w treatment

title: ALKP
detail:
• Alkaline phosphatase
• Found in bone, liver, and other tissues
• Can increase due to liver disease or
• In growing animals
• In dental disease
• In animals w acute bone injury, arthritis
• Due to use of antiseizure medications (most commonly phenobarbital) and corticosteroids

title: Stress in cattle
detail:
• Mild
• Eyes widened and head elevated (both slightly), mouth closed
• Moving away from sounds and people
• Seeking out companionship
• Still eating
• Moderate
• Wide eyes w visible sclera, darting around for danger
• Trying to escape or freezing
• Tail close to the body or tucked, or in inverted U shape
• Startle easily
• Severe
• Wide eyes w visible sclera, also rolling
• Bulls may charge
• Pawing at the ground, pointing heads towards danger
• Wagging tail vigorously, often as precursor to a kick (in all directions!)

title: Drain care
detail:
• Remove any serous discharge around the drain hole and skin using warm water soaks w gauze; prevents scalding and bacterial infection
• Petroleum jelly around the area once dried helps dry and protect the skin and lessens risk of scalding and irritation
• Antibiotic ointments are avoided since pet is usually on antibiotics
• E-collar and separation from other pets necessary
• X-rays may be needed if pet removes drain to make sure none of it remains inside (can become a focal point for bacterial infection)
• Pet should be seen right away if serous discharge changes color, becomes thick, develops odor (antibiotics not enough)

title: Hostile workplace
detail:
• Discrimination
• Inability to perform work duties effectively due to actions of others
• Engaging in behavior to get an employee to quit
• Physical threat

title: Methods of acceptable equine euthanasia
detail:
• Lethal IV doses of barbiturates
• Gunshot to the brain, w pre-sedation if possible
• Penetrating captive bolt to the brain (delivers forceful blow causing immediate unconsciousness and death), w pre-sedation if possible
• Lidocaine hydrochloride 2% intrathecal w horse in surgical anesthetic plane (injected into the spinal cord or subarachnoid space to travel to brain)
• IV magnesium sulfate or IV potassium chloride under surgical anesthetic plane

title: Goal of euthanasia
detail:
• Ending an animal’s life peacefully and giving them a good quality death
• Not humane killing, since it might give time for distress, pain, and suffering (e.g. snap traps for mice)

title: AVMA’s 12 criteria for humane euthanasia
detail:
• Ability to induce loss of consciousness and death w/out triggering pain, distress, fear
• Reasonable time (short) to induce loss of consciousness
• Safety for staff and clients
• Irreversibility
• Reliability
• Emotional effect on those present
• Compatibility w future examination (necropsy)
• Drug availability, consideration to human abuse risk
• Ability to maintain equipment (IV)
• Safety for predators/scavengers when private burial is used
• Compatibility w the patient, species, health status, age
• Compatibility w requirement and purpose

title: Dysthanasia
detail: • Suffering by the pet or the client during euthanasia

title: Horse travel
detail:
• All states require a negative Coggins test w/in 6-12 mo of travel to issue an interstate health certificate
• For equine infectious anemia, a viral disease transmitted by biting flies (tabinids)
• Many horses are asymptomatic carriers
• Blood must be drawn by an USDA-accredited vet
• Even w/out travel, all horses must be tested annually
• Infected horses must be quarantined for life
• Valid physical exam also required for travel
• Vaccines may be required depending on location and purpose
• Some states offer Extended Equine Certificate of Veterinary Inspection (eeCVI) that meets interstate health needs; valid for 6 mo

title: Indications for necropsy
detail:
• Determine cause of death
• Determine the accuracy of a clinical diagnosis
• Evaluate effects of treatment measures
• Define disease processes that contribute to death
• Determine treatment plans for other animals at risk

title: Indications for recommending mental health assistance for end of life
detail:
• Client hints at suicide
• Client requests staff lies to family members, incl. kids
• Discordance among family members about end-of-life wishes
• Client is wishy-washy
• Client can’t comprehend disease, problem, or decisions needed to move forward
• Hospice care is interfering w client’s work or care
• Client verbalizes trouble adjusting to loss

title: Reproduction in guinea pigs
detail:
• Sexual maturity in starts at 2 months in females and bw 2-3 months in males
• Gestational length is 59-72 days (long for size)
• First pregnancy must be before 8 months of age, otherwise pubic symphysis will fuse and necessitate C-section or cause dystocia
• Ideal is before 6 mo to avoid risk

title: One-quarter mastitis in cattle
detail:
• Most important thing is to palpate all teats for signs of heat, infection, and pain
• Then sanitize teats and dry individually
• Then being milking by grasping teat firmly, pinching at the base with a fist and sliding the pinch toward the end of the teat

title: Key information for medical records when establishing a new client/patient
detail:
• Previous medical problems
• Previous therapies and response to tx
• Previous meds
• Adverse reactions to meds
• History of transfusion, if so any reactions
• Previous surgeries
• Weight history and trends
• Previous diets, rx diets, non-tolerated foods
• Geographic area where patient was born and raised
• Travel history

title: Onychectomy post-op care
detail:
• Very painful, pain management important
• Post-op bleeding is not common, so must be checked
• E-collar a must
• Paper litter preferred (CareFresh)
• Inflammation should be checked
• Jumping must be prevented; may lead to chronic lameness or neuropathic pain
• Must remain indoors even after recovery

title: Gestational periods for large animals
detail:
• Pigs: 112-115 days
• Sheep and goat: 145-152 days
• Cows: 279-283 days
• Horses: 330-345 days (310-365 days)
• Camelids (incl. alpaca): 340-350 days

title: Areas to avoid during massage
detail:
• Areas of infection
• Areas of acute injury
• Inflamed areas
• Areas w open wounds
• Areas where neoplasia is present
• Endangerment sites
• Eyes, throat, brachial plexus, abdomen (over kidneys or deep tissue near aorta)

title: By-products (nutrition)
detail:
• Side products left after another product is made
• Doesn’t indicate poor quality
• Primarily organ meats (highly nutritional), blood, bone
• Most are found in treats (unregulated)
• Don’t include hooves, hair, horns, teeth
• Improve palatability w/out fillers

title: Vocal characterizer cues
detail:
• Voice pitch
• Speech rate
• Speech volume
• Not emotional tone—falls under emotional characterizers

title: Weaning kittens
detail:
• Kittens usually nurse for min. of 6 weeks, can go as long as 8-10 weeks if mom is around
• Good quality, digestible kitten food should be introduced at 3 weeks
• Gives time for GI to adapt
• Orphaned kittens can be weaned faster once they are eating sufficient amounts of kitten food

title: Functions of medical records
detail:
• Primary functions:
• Proper identification of patient and client
• Supporting communication among team and client
• Providing support and documentation of diagnostics, procedures, treatment plans
• Personalizes VCPR (vet-client-patient relationship)
• Supporting continuity of care
• Secondary functions:
• Billing verification
• Supporting analysis of business for staffing, budgeting
• Supporting individual and collective accreditation
• Serving as legal document in the event of malpractice or insurance claims
• Supporting research (case studies, education, database)

title: Methods of identifying dairy herds
detail:
• Ear tagging
• Freeze branding (liquid nitrogen, dry ice)
• Tattooing inside ear pinna
• Ankle straps
• Neck tags
• Transponder (usually on the neck, read by scanner)
